titles: Mad Max: Fury Road, Some Thoughts | Tim Scotson
Mad Max: Fury Road, Some Thoughts

text: Mad Max: Fury Road, Some Thoughts

texts.html: June 2, 2015June 2, 2015 | TJScotson

Like a lot of people I can’t stop thinking about Mad Max: Fury Road. I finally saw it for myself this Sunday past and have been picking it apart ever since. It is an unrelentingly glorious film that deserves every bit of critical praise and commercial success it has been receiving since its release and then some. In fact, it may very well end up being the best movie of the year.
text: Like a lot of people I can’t stop thinking about

. I finally saw it for myself this Sunday past and have been picking it apart ever since. It is an unrelentingly glorious film that deserves every bit of critical praise and commercial success it has been receiving since its release and then some. In fact, it may very well end up being the best movie of the year.

texts.html: I made a comment upon leaving the theatre that I thought Fury Road might have been the smartest dumb movie I’d ever seen, but upon further reflection I don’t think that there is anything dumb about it. It’s completely and utterly insane, for sure, but it isn’t dumb. Everything in Fury Road is put there with a great deal of precision and purpose and it shows. George Miller is 70 years old now, and Fury Road has all the hallmarks of something pieced together by an old master of his craft. What is really impressive though is how vivid, vibrant and lively the whole thing feels. You would be forgiven for assuming that this was the work of a much younger director, but I doubt there are many directors working in the industry these days with the chops to make a movie that is both as joyously insane, exciting and fun while still being as smart and, most impressively, subtle as this movie manages.

has all the hallmarks of something pieced together by an old master of his craft. What is really impressive though is how vivid, vibrant and lively the whole thing feels. You would be forgiven for assuming that this was the work of a much younger director, but I doubt there are many directors working in the industry these days with the chops to make a movie that is both as joyously insane, exciting and fun while still being as smart and, most impressively, subtle as this movie manages.

texts.html: Yes, this blazing fever-dream of an action movie about a post-apocalyptic waste-land filled with insane cultists, cars that are more spike than vehicle, and flame-thrower guitars manages to be a subtle movie. It doesn’t do this on its surface of course -that layer is all bombast and explosions- but in the way that it pieces all of its elements together to create layers below the surface that are fascinating and rich in their own right.
text: Yes, this blazing fever-dream of an action movie about a post-apocalyptic waste-land filled with insane cultists, cars that are more spike than vehicle, and flame-thrower guitars manages to be a subtle movie. It doesn’t do this on its surface of course -that layer is all bombast and explosions- but in the way that it pieces all of its elements together to create layers below the surface that are fascinating and rich in their own right.

texts.html: A brief digression: There was, unsurprisingly, much talk about whether Avengers: Age of Ultron was as good as its predecessor. Both are fantastic movies -though I think the first one edges it out- but apart from them both being Avengers movies I don’t think the two of them make for a fair comparison of quality. Avengers Assemble (as it was titled here in the UK) was at its heart an ensemble buddy movie and its narrative focus was firmly placed on the character arcs of its protagonists. By contrast Age of Ultron was largely disinterested in character growth (save for a few moments putting a pin in the end of some of the multi-movie arcs) but rather was more interested in talking thematically. It’s a movie about parenthood, and families and legacy and responsibility and it delivers on those ideas wonderfully without being particularly bothered about characters having traditional ‘arcs’. Neither method of storytelling is inherently better than the other, though it could be argued that character arcs allow an audience to invest in a story more easily. Certainly this accounts for the greater difference of opinion on Age of Ultron’s quality, both in the abstract and relative to its predecessor. To my mind what elevates this latest Mad Max above the rest of the current crop of action movie faire is the way it manages to be a story both about character arcs and thematics without that ever getting in the way of the movie being fun.

texts.html: Cinema, we are so frequently reminded, is an art that is about showing not telling and Fury Road is an exemplar of this style of story-telling. The proof of George Miller’s mastery of his craft then is in not only how he weaves theme and character arcs together into one single thread but uses the former to construct the latter. Every single element of Fury Road is there in support of its intricate structure and these things allow it to be both a very big movie and a very small one at the same time.

is an exemplar of this style of story-telling. The proof of George Miller’s mastery of his craft then is in not only how he weaves theme and character arcs together into one single thread but uses the former to construct the latter. Every single element of
is there in support of its intricate structure and these things allow it to be both a very big movie and a very small one at the same time.

texts.html: I wanted to walk you through an example of one character’s arcs by way of showcasing the kind of intricate way that everything in this movie connects itself to everything else, but about half-way through I realised that to do so would take up far more space than I want to spend here on this blog. It is impossible to talk about any one element of the film without talking about everything and I could write thousands of words on the subject if I had both the time and inclination (and a copy of the film to examine more critically than one cinema viewing would allow) but at this stage I simply don’t. Suffice it to say that every character’s arc reinforces and is reinforced by the film’s themes of redemption, people as objects or agents, hope, and sanity.
text: I wanted to walk you through an example of one character’s arcs by way of showcasing the kind of intricate way that everything in this movie connects itself to everything else, but about half-way through I realised that to do so would take up far more space than I want to spend here on this blog. It is impossible to talk about any one element of the film without talking about everything and I could write thousands of words on the subject if I had both the time and inclination (and a copy of the film to examine more critically than one cinema viewing would allow) but at this stage I simply don’t. Suffice it to say that every character’s arc reinforces and is reinforced by the film’s themes of redemption, people as objects or agents, hope, and sanity.

texts.html: As it stands each of the primary characters has a valuable and interesting journey they take. For Max it is a simple one; a journey from fleeing from his own mind to embracing it, from being someone who simply survives to someone with a cause again, even if the cause is one he finds himself caught up in entirely by accident. Max is not the films true protagonist though. Rather, he serves as the audience perspective for the story of Imperator Furiosa. Charlize Theron is wonderful as Furiosa, who’s quest to free Immortan Joe’s five ‘wives’ from their slavery dominates the movie. She presents the character as battle-hardened, determined and courageous without sacrificing her femininity. This is in fact true of all of the female characters in the film (of which there are plenty) and it makes for an intensely refreshing breath of air in a climate where action movies and ‘bad ass heroes’ are synonymous with masculinity.
text: As it stands each of the primary characters has a valuable and interesting journey they take. For Max it is a simple one; a journey from fleeing from his own mind to embracing it, from being someone who simply survives to someone with a cause again, even if the cause is one he finds himself caught up in entirely by accident. Max is not the films true protagonist though. Rather, he serves as the audience perspective for the story of Imperator Furiosa. Charlize Theron is wonderful as Furiosa, who’s quest to free Immortan Joe’s five ‘wives’ from their slavery dominates the movie. She presents the character as battle-hardened, determined and courageous without sacrificing her femininity. This is in fact true of all of the female characters in the film (of which there are plenty) and it makes for an intensely refreshing breath of air in a climate where action movies and ‘bad ass heroes’ are synonymous with masculinity.

texts.html: It could be argued (and I’d probably agree) that it is a sad state of affairs that ‘the female characters actually feel like female characters’ is such a large point in the movie’s favour, but that is the state of affairs and to get a movie like this that bucks those trends is noteworthy. So I am taking note of it. In fact a lot has been made about how feminist this latest Mad Max is and whether or not it is making a statement. Personally I think it is, but just like everything else in the film it is doing it subtly and by showing and not telling.
text: It could be argued (and I’d probably agree) that it is a sad state of affairs that ‘the female characters actually feel like female characters’ is such a large point in the movie’s favour, but that is the state of affairs and to get a movie like this that bucks those trends
noteworthy. So I am taking note of it. In fact a lot has been made about how feminist this latest
is and whether or not it is making a statement. Personally I think it is, but just like everything else in the film it is doing it subtly and by showing and not telling.

texts.html: The central conflict of the film is one woman attempting to free five others from sexual slavery. Having escaped Imperator Joe’s clutches the five women leave behind various messages painted in white upon the walls of their old prison. Most prominently is the message ‘we are not things’, cementing firmly in the mind of the audience one of the film’s most prominent themes. This conflict is one that, to my mind is impossible to read -in the context of modern film-making and western culture’s ongoing discussion about how we view and treat women- as anything other than a statement for feminism. (For the record, different people seem to have different understandings of the word feminism but for my part I understand it to be a movement about ensuring that people are treated equally and respectfully regardless of gender.) Fury Road however is not interested in making its statement simply by shouting ‘hey look, treating women as objects is bad!’ It’s far smarter than that. Rather, it uses this conflict to put the audience in mind of these things, and then stops talking and starts showing.
text: The central conflict of the film is one woman attempting to free five others from sexual slavery. Having escaped Imperator Joe’s clutches the five women leave behind various messages painted in white upon the walls of their old prison. Most prominently is the message ‘we are not things’, cementing firmly in the mind of the audience one of the film’s most prominent themes. This conflict is one that, to my mind is impossible to read -in the context of modern film-making and western culture’s ongoing discussion about how we view and treat women- as anything other than a statement for feminism. (For the record, different people seem to have different understandings of the word feminism but for my part I understand it to be a movement about ensuring that people are treated equally and respectfully regardless of gender.)

however is not interested in making its statement simply by shouting ‘hey look, treating women as objects is bad!’ It’s far smarter than that. Rather, it uses this conflict to put the audience in mind of these things, and then stops talking and starts showing.

texts.html: Furiosa is heroic not because or for the sake of a man, but for other women and for herself. The five women she has rescued from Immortan Joe would, in a lesser movie have been reduced to backdrops, dramatic ‘objects’ used to further the plot without having much story of their own. Here though, each of them has distinct character. All of them respond differently to the situation they find themselves in, be it with fear or bravado or prayer and all of them feel like human beings. They make themselves useful by fighting or re-loading weapons (or don’t because they have no idea how to load a gun, depending on the character) and in one particularly brilliant scene one of them puts herself in the way of a shot that Joe is aiming at Furiosa, banking on him not being willing to damage his ‘property’ or risk killing his unborn child. The women in this movie are allowed to fill roles that are traditionally female – mothers, care-givers, etc. whilst still being active agents, excellent shots, driving absurd motorcycles and generally kicking ass. This is a film that makes its statements not by telling the audience what it thinks but simply by existing. It shows us that not only can letting women’s stories take centre stage be just as good as letting men’s, but that allowing all your characters to be agents makes for better and richer story telling. Rather than simply condemning other stories for reducing women to objects Fury Road illustrates than when you stop doing that your stories become richer, more interesting and all around better. If that isn’t a feminist stance I don’t know what is.

This is a film that makes its statements not by telling the audience what it thinks but simply by existing. It shows us that not only can letting women’s stories take centre stage be just as good as letting men’s, but that allowing all your characters to be agents makes for better and richer story telling. Rather than simply condemning other stories for reducing women to objects
illustrates than when you stop doing that your stories become richer, more interesting and all around better. If that isn’t a feminist stance I don’t know what is.

texts.html: Finally, I couldn’t talk about this film for this long and not mention how unrelentingly beautiful it is. I am a sucker for visuals that do bold and interesting things with light and colour (which is why I like Zack Snyder as a director so much) and this is a film that doesn’t frame a shot so much as it paints it. The night time scenes are washed in a deep and rich blue whilst the daytime scenes are vibrant, popping yellows reds and oranges. The pale cream of the salt flats or burning umber of the desert sands make the pale blues of the sky and moments of clear water stand out like beacons  and the rare, rare moments of green are intensely striking.
text: Finally, I couldn’t talk about this film for this long and not mention how unrelentingly

it is. I am a sucker for visuals that do bold and interesting things with light and colour (which is why I like Zack Snyder as a director so much) and this is a film that doesn’t frame a shot so much as it paints it. The night time scenes are washed in a deep and rich blue whilst the daytime scenes are vibrant, popping yellows reds and oranges. The pale cream of the salt flats or burning umber of the desert sands make the pale blues of the sky and moments of clear water stand out like beacons  and the rare, rare moments of green are intensely striking.

texts.html: The shots are framed incredibly too, often making the film look as though it was torn from the pages of a comic book and plastered onto the screen. This effect is only heightened by the sheer absurdity of its design aesthetic with rusty, battered vehicles made up of the cannibalised remains of the old, now dead world. Spikes and shiny chrome skulls adorn everything and create a visual language that is as internally coherent and rich as it is anarchic. This is a different kind of beauty, one that applies only to a world that had been turned entirely into ash and rubble but it makes the world of Mad Max feel as perfectly insane as the personalities that populate it.
text: The shots are framed incredibly too, often making the film look as though it was torn from the pages of a comic book and plastered onto the screen. This effect is only heightened by the sheer absurdity of its design aesthetic with rusty, battered vehicles made up of the cannibalised remains of the old, now dead world. Spikes and shiny chrome skulls adorn

and create a visual language that is as internally coherent and rich as it is anarchic. This is a different kind of beauty, one that applies only to a world that had been turned entirely into ash and rubble but it makes the world of
feel as perfectly insane as the personalities that populate it.

texts.html: Fury Road is a beautifully absurd and bonkers movie that still manages to be clever, intricate, engaging and poignant without ever harming how fun it is. It is certainly the best thing that I’ve seen so far this year and will take something truly incredible to top it. George Miller has proven himself an absolute master of his craft and an excellent argument against the idea that directors lose their edge the older they get. It will, I suspect, be a long time before we see an action blockbuster of this calibre again.

It will, I suspect, be a long time before we see an action blockbuster of this calibre again.
